title: The White House Says Its Plans Will Slow Inflation. The Big Question Is: When?
content: The Biden administration has argued that its infrastructure and broader economic package will slow rapid price increases. But that will take time.

more_info.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley

title: Now TV Wants Nielsen to Measure Up
content: After years of complaints, NBCUniversal and its peers are looking for other ways to count viewers, with or without the ratings giant.

title: What Bosses Really Think About the Future of the Office
content: C.E.O.s are eager for employees to return — and afraid of alienating those who have grown accustomed to working from home.

title: Tips for Holding Down Your Winter Heating Bills
content: Start with insulating the attic and turning down the thermostat at night. And there’s always your father’s advice: Wear a sweater.

title: Project Veritas and the Line Between Journalism and Political Spying
content: Documents show how the conservative group worked with lawyers to gauge how far its deceptive reporting practices could go before running afoul of federal laws.

more_info.byline: By Adam Goldman and Mark Mazzetti

title: Dream of Buying a Home Gets Harder for Single Mothers
content: Lost pay during the pandemic and high costs threaten strides they had made in homeownership, often a key driver of long-term wealth.

org_facet: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp (Freddie Mac)

title: Stocks Soar in India, Luring Investors at Home and Abroad
content: The second-most populous country is enjoying some of the world’s strongest stock market returns. Pro-growth policies and gnawing questions about China have helped.

more_info.byline: By Matt Phillips and Emily Schmall

title: A New Mercedes SL Stresses Horsepower and Verve
content: Across seven decades, the roadster has radiated a sporty elegance, and a new generation adds a dash of modern driving technology.

title: These Investors May Believe Biden on Inflation
content: Has the president found a corner of the market that has faith in his pledge to contain rising prices?

more_info.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni

title: Johnson & Johnson will break itself into two companies.
content: The corporate giant said it would spin off its consumer products division, leaving the company to manufacture and market drugs and medical devices.

more_info.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

title: 275 Minutes on Hold: Why Airline Customer Service Still Can’t Keep Up
content: It’s been a familiar and infuriating story during the pandemic: Hours waiting for an agent only to have the call dropped. The ordeal of rescheduling canceled flights. Delayed refunds. What gives?

title: What We Learned From Tim Cook, Antony Blinken, Mary Barra and More
content: China, inflation, electric vehicles, deplatforming and other hot topics dominated the DealBook Online Summit this year.

more_info.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni

title: Britain’s economic recovery has slowed as supply disruptions persist.
content: The economy grew 1.3 percent in the third quarter, down from 5.5 percent growth in the previous three months.

title: Alibaba reports slower sales growth for its Singles Day shopping event.
content: Sales grew 8.5 percent from last year, but had grown 26 percent in 2020 from the year before.

title: The Core Legal Strategy Against Opioid Companies May Be Faltering
content: Two recent rulings rejected the “public nuisance” argument being used in thousands of cases against the industry, with more trials and settlement talks underway.

title: California Businessman Is Sentenced to 30 Years in $1 Billion Ponzi Scheme
content: Jeff Carpoff, 50, ran a Ponzi scheme with his wife that sold nonexistent solar generators to investors, prosecutors said.

title: Elon Musk sells $5 billion in Tesla shares, partly to cover taxes on stock options.
content: The sales so far were considerably short of the $20 billion worth he promised over the weekend that he would sell.

title: Ten states sue the U.S. over the vaccine mandate for health care workers.
content: The suit claims that the rule “threatens with job loss millions of health care workers who risked their lives.”

org_facet: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services

title: Key takeaways from Week 10 of the Elizabeth Holmes trial.
content: Two former lab directors testified about some of the inner workings of Theranos.

title: Cherry Lane Theater Is Back on the Market After Sale Falls Through
content: It seemed as if the Lucille Lortel Theater Foundation’s purchase of the theater was a done deal in July. But now the property is back on the market.

title: Ozy Media Faces Federal Investigations
content: The Justice Department and the S.E.C. have contacted companies that discussed investing in the Silicon Valley media business.

more_info.byline: By Ben Smith and Ben Protess

title: Disney+ subscriber growth slowed notably in latest quarter, putting pressure on the company.
content: Disney is beginning a new marketing blitz to promote its all-important streaming service.

title: Boeing agrees to accept responsibility for crash of its 737 Max jet in Ethiopia.
content: The company will pay out successful compensation suits and allow victims’ families to file those suits in Illinois. Families agreed not to sue for punitive damages.

des_facet: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)

title: Daniel Lee Is Leaving Bottega Veneta
content: In a surprise split, the designer responsible for the brand’s revival is out.

org_facet: Council of Fashion Designers of America

title: U.S. sues Uber, saying it discriminated against people with disabilities.
content: The Justice Department says Uber did not adjust its wait time fees for people with disabilities, even when Uber knew someone needed additional time.

title: China Evergrande meets another interest payment deadline.
content: Evergrande had three bonds for which grace periods for interest payments were set to expire on Wednesday.

title: Rivian I.P.O. Is Embraced by Investors Looking for Another Tesla
content: The electric-vehicle maker, backed by Amazon and Ford, ended its first day of trading valued at $86 billion, though its deliveries so far total 156.

more_info.byline: By Peter Eavis and Neal E. Boudette
des_facet: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks

title: Is Denim in an Identity Crisis?
content: Low slung, high waisted, skinny, cropped, baggy, flared — there’s no consensus on jeans these days. What does that say about the era we’re living through? And what can it tell us about ourselves?

more_info.byline: By Haley Nahman and OK McCausland

title: Antony Blinken says ‘we have fallen short’ on global vaccine distribution.
content: The Secretary of State called for rich countries, pharmaceutical companies and others to “step up.”

title: When a Logo Doesn’t Risk It All: Meta’s Brand Is Designed for Unknown Worlds
content: The emblem for Facebook’s new parent company is built for the metaverse, even if it disappoints in the real world.

title: What’s happening today at the DealBook summit.
China, Electric Vehicles and More at the DealBook Online Summit
content: What we want to know from Secretary of State Antony Blinken, G.M.’s Mary Barra, the podcast hosts Dax Shepard and Monica Padman, and more.
